title: Is it grammatically correct to say 'A is twice bigger than B'? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, it’s not correct because “twice” is modifying the word “bigger” when you actually mean to modify the phrase “A is bigger than B.” In this particular instance the difference is trivial and you will still be understood, but if you used a different comparison you might be out of luck. When you’re modifying phrases like this, you have to ensure the whole phrase is clumped together and then modify it by adding a phrase beside it (usually a prepositional phrase). You can say: A is bigger than B by a factor of two. Here you’ve got two phrases. “By a factor of two” describes the whole phrase “A is bigger than B” by qualifying how much larger A is. If you really want to slide twice into the middle, you can, but not with “big.” Big cannot take a modifier in the middle of the comparison in that form. A is twice as big as B. In classical English, “Big” technically can’t support this construction, so strictly speaking I should have used “large.” Why can large do this and big can’t? I don’t know, but in spoken or informal English it’s not really a mistake worth marking; native speakers do it all the time. In any case, the difference here is that “twice” describes the whole phrase “as big as B.” Get the pattern? An adjective of scale always describes the whole comparison, and has to be placed so that’s apparent.

No. Here are examples of, and suggestions for, proper usage: EXAMPLES: A is twice as big as B.A is twice the size of B.A is two times bigger than B.REMEMBER: “As” and “than” wouldn't appear in the same comparative phrase.“As” gets a matching “as” in the same comparative phrase.I hope this is helpful.
